thread.title: Corruption Currents: Ex-Brazil President Lula Surrenders

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Ex-Brazil President Lula Surrenders
text:
0 COMMENTS Brazil's former president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (center), leaves the metal workers union headquarters in Sao Bernardo do Campo on Saturday. Photo: Associated Press 
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk and compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk. 
Bribery: 
South Korea filed charges against former a president, Lee Myung-bak, accusing him of bribery. He denied the allegations. (Yonhap, AFP)
The offices of Eni SpA in Republic of Congo were searched . A company spokesman said Eni complied. (Reuters)
The chief executive of Petrofac received a $1 million bonus despite undergoing questioning about bribery. He denied wrongdoing. (Times)
Local cases: A convicted businessman and his son were charged with paying bribes to a South Florida politician and a lobbyist. Indian authorities arrested a judge. A former union worker pleaded guilty . (MH, DC, AP)
Cybercrime: 
The details of Russian hacking of U.S. voting systems continue to unravel. (CBS)
Singaporean regulators told banks to be more vigilant. (ST)
Best Buy Co. Inc. warned its customers their data may have been compromised. (AP)
Fraud: 
An American company was duped into sending millions to a Hong Kong bank account. (SCMP)
A woman was jailed for fraud after pretending to be a victim of the Grenfell fire. (Guardian, BBC)
Money Laundering: 
JPMorgan admitted it knew a former Nigerian oil minister convicted of money laundering would benefit when approving a transfer of $800 million in government assets to a company he controlled. (Reuters, PT)
Venezuela halted commercial ties with Panama over money-laundering allegations . The U.S. welcomed the move. (Reuters, VOA)
The U.K. won’t say how many estate agents were fined for money-laundering compliance failures. (EAT, PIE)
U.K. police seized bitcoin allegedly laundered through the Second Life video game. (Bitcoinist)
Malta’s new financial regulator said Deutsche Bank AG is known as a money-laundering channel. The story didn’t contain a response from the bank. (ToM)
A Pennsylvania court agreed to delay a money-laundering trial. (Law360)
Indian authorities continue their work on money laundering cases . (Zee, BS, AA, PTI, LM)
Sanctions: 
India and Russia are set to strike a missile deal despite Western sanctions. The latest U.S. sanctions on Russia come during the release of a whitepaper on fighting kleptocracy. Former U.S. officials praised the latest measures ; will they have their desired impact ? (Zee, DB, NPR, KI, National, NYT, NY, NPR)
A secret Russian airlift is helping Syria evade sanctions. (Reuters)
China narrowed its military sales to North Korea as part of its own pressure campaign. (AP)
Whistleblowers: 
A tipster alleged corruption at the U.S. Department of Energy. A department spokeswoman called the claims ridiculous. (NY)
General Anti-Corruption: 
Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, surrendered to police and began his prison term for corruption. The country’s citizens take stock of life following his imprisonment . (BBC, NYT, Guardian, G&M, DT)
Former South African president Jacob Zuma sat defiant as his corruption trial began . His supporters tried to drown out the allegations. The current president referred allegations of corruption at the state utility to a special prosecutor; the company denied wrongdoing. (AP, BBC, AFP, Verdict, BBC)
Facebook confirmed nearly 3 million European accounts were ensnared in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Brazilian authorities fined Facebook for failing to comply with requests in a corruption case. Cambridge Analytica played a role in the 2013 Philippines election. Facebook announced new rules on issue ads. (Reuters, OCCRP, Rappler, WP)
Saudi Arabia’s public prosecutor began investigations against those that didn’t settle during the corruption drive. (AJE, Reuters)
The Mugabe family faces allegations of ivory smuggling. (Bloomberg)
A federal judge dismissed charges against Utah’s attorney general. (AP)
The U.S. special counsel’s probe continues as new leads emerge . Experts say the probe will plumb unchartered waters . (AJE, NYT, ABC, DB, AJE, USAT, Politico, ACS)
